chapter.title: 24 Aerococcus, Abiotrophia, and Other Aerobic Catalase-Negative, Gram-Positive Cocci

sect1.title: 24 Aerococcus, Abiotrophia, and Other Aerobic Catalase-Negative, Gram-Positive Cocci

para.phrase: XIAOHUI CHEN NIELSEN AND JENS JØRGEN CHRISTENSEN

sect2.title: TAXONOMY
sect2.para: The catalase-negative, Gram-positive cocci included in this chapter form a taxonomically diverse group of bacteria that are isolated infrequently as opportunistic agents of infection. Most of these organisms resemble other, better-known clinical isolates (i.e., streptococci and enterococci) and consequently may be mistaken for members of those genera. Although probably misidentified or overlooked in clinical cultures in the past, these organisms may represent emerging pathogens in immunocompromised patient populations.Table 1 lists the organisms included here, along with some of their basic characteristics. The bacteria discussed in this chapter are members of the phylum Firmicutes (low-G+C, Gram-positive bacteria). Except for the genera Helcococcus (class Clostridia) and Gemella (order Bacillales), these genera are classified in the class Bacilli and in the order Lactobacillales (1, 2). The order Lactobacillales encompasses the families Aerococcaceae, Carnobacteriaceae, Enterococcaceae, Lactobacillaceae, Leuconostocaceae, and Streptococcaceae. Genera mentioned in this chapter belonging to these families are Aerococcus, Abiotrophia, and Facklamia and the so-called minor genera Dolosicoccus, Eremococcus, Globicatella, and Ignavigranum (in the Aerococcaceae), Alloiococcus, Dolosigranulum, and Granulicatella (in the Carnobacteriaceae), Tetragenococcus and Vagococcus (in the Enterococcaceae), Pediococcus (in the Lactobacillaceae), Leuconostoc and Weissella (in the Leuconostocaceae), and Lactococcus (in the Streptococcaceae). See chapter 21 for information on Rothia mucilaginosa, another infrequently isolated Gram-positive coccus that may be catalase negative.

The genusLactococcus is composed of organisms formerly classified as Lancefield group N streptococci (3). The species Lactococcus lactis and Lactococcus garvieae have been documented in human infections. Motile Lactococcus-like organisms with the Lancefield group N antigen (a teichoic acid antigen) are classified in the genus Vagococcus (4). Vagococcus fluvialis has been isolated from human blood culture, wounds, peritoneal fluid, cerebrospinal fluid, and root canal (5). A newly described species, Vagococcus vulneris, was isolated from a human foot wound (6). The vagococci also resemble the enterococci, as noted by Facklam and Elliott (7).

The generaAbiotrophia and Granulicatella include organisms previously known as nutritionally variant or satelliting streptococci (8, 9). These bacteria were originally thought to be nutritional mutants of viridans group streptococcal strains, most notably of the species Streptococcus mitis. A comparative analysis of 16S rRNA gene sequences led Kawamura and coworkers to propose the creation of a new genus, Abiotrophia, containing two species, Abiotrophia defectiva and Abiotrophia adiacens, to accommodate these bacteria (9). A third species from human sources, Abiotrophia elegans, was described in 1998 (10). In 2000, Collins and Lawson proposed a new genus, Granulicatella, with Granulicatella adiacens and Granulicatella elegans representing strains formerly called A. adiacens and A. elegans. A. defectiva remains as the sole Abiotrophia species (8).

Among the intrinsically vancomycin-resistant, catalase-negative, Gram-positive cocci, a number ofLeuconostoc species have been noted in human infection (Leuconostoc mesenteroides, Leuconostoc lactis, Leuconostoc pseudomesenteroides, and Leuconostoc citreum [11]). In 1993, the former Leuconostoc paramesenteroides and related species were placed into a novel genus, Weissella (12). Twenty-four species of Weissella have been recognized and validly published (https://lpsn.dsmz.de/genus/weissella; accessed 30 December 2021); however, only three have been detected in human specimens: Weissella confusa, W. cibaria, and W. viridescens (13). Pediococcus acidilactici and Pediococcus pentosaceus are the most common clinical isolates of pediococci (14). The vancomycin-susceptible species formerly named Pediococcus halophilus was reclassified in the genus Tetragenococcus (15). The organism formerly called Enterococcus solitarius has also been transferred to the genus Tetragenococcus as Tetragenococcus solitarius (16). Tetragenococcus is known to contribute to food fermentation; however, little is known about the role of the tetragenococci in human infection.

The organism we now know asGemella morbillorum was described as Diplococcus rubeolae in 1917 by Tunnicliff (17) as isolates from the blood of patients with measles. Later, G. morbillorum was named Peptostreptococcus morbillorum and Streptococcus morbillorum until a proposal to include it in the genus Gemella as G. morbillorum was made in 1988 (18). A second species, Gemella haemolysans, was originally classified as a Neisseria species, due to its Gram-variable or even Gram-negative nature and its cellular morphology (diplococci with flattened adjacent sides). Collins and coworkers described two additional Gemella species isolated from human sources, Gemella bergeri (originally named Gemella bergeriae [19]) and Gemella sanguinis (20). Three other species, Gemella asaccharolytica (21), Gemella parahaemolysans, and Gemella taiwanensis (22), were also isolated from human clinical specimens. The genus Dolosigranulum, with its single species Dolosigranulum pigrum, shows phenotypic similarities to Gemella, although it is not phylogenetically closely related to Gemella strains (23, 24).

Aerococcus urinae, described in 1992, is negative for pyrrolidonyl arylamidase production (PYR) and positive for leucine aminopeptidase production (LAP), showing reactions opposite those of Aerococcus viridans in these important identification tests (25, 26). Aerococcus christensenii, isolated from the human genitourinary tract, was described by Collins and coworkers in 1999 (27) and was joined by the species Aerococcus sanguinicola (originally named Aerococcus sanguicola [28, 29]) and Aerococcus urinaehominis (30) in 2001. Complete whole-genome sequences of these five Aerococcus type strains have been obtained (31).

Globicatella, Facklamia, Ignavigranum, and Dolosicoccus are related genera that are isolated infrequently from clinical specimens. Globicatella sanguinis, initially named Globicatella sanguis, was described in 1992 (32). Facklamia currently contains four species isolated from human sources: Facklamia hominis (33), Facklamia sourekii (34), Facklamia ignava (35), and Facklamia languida (36). The genus Ignavigranum, currently consisting of a single species, Ignavigranum ruoffiae, was described by Collins and coworkers (37), along with the genus Dolosicoccus and its single species, Dolosicoccus paucivorans (38).

The genusHelcococcus, originally composed of the single species Helcococcus kunzii (39), came to include a new species isolated from humans, Helcococcus sueciensis, in 2004 (40). Helcococcus ovis, isolated from infections in animals, displays satelliting growth, unlike the human Helcococcus species (41).

sect2.title: DESCRIPTION OF THE GENERA
sect2.para: The organisms included in this chapter form Gram-positive coccoid cells, butG. haemolysans may appear Gram variable or Gram negative due to the ease with which its cells are decolorized. Cell shape and arrangement can be used to divide these organisms into two broad groups: those with a “streptococcal” Gram stain (coccobacilli in pairs and chains) and those with a “staphylococcal” Gram stain (more spherical cocci in pairs, tetrads, clusters, or irregular groups). Dividing these diverse bacteria into two groups based on cellular shape and arrangement serves only as an aid in identification; no relatedness of organisms is implied by this grouping. Abiotrophia and Granulicatella isolates (formerly the nutritionally variant streptococci) form coccobacilli arranged in pairs and chains, but these organisms may also appear pleomorphic, especially when grown under suboptimal nutritional conditions (42). With the exception of the infrequently isolated vagococci, these bacteria are all nonmotile. Most of the genera described here are catalase-negative facultative anaerobes, but A. viridans is classified as a microaerophile that grows poorly, if at all, under anaerobic conditions. Some strains of Aerococcus may exhibit weakly positive catalase reactions due to nonheme catalase activity. None of the genera is beta-hemolytic on routinely employed blood agars, but strains of G. haemolysans, G. bergeri, and G. sanguinis have been described as beta-hemolytic on agars supplemented with horse blood (19, 20, 43).

sect2.title: EPIDEMIOLOGY AND TRANSMISSION
sect2.para: The organisms discussed in this chapter are opportunistic pathogens. Some of the genera have been characterized as constituents of the normal microbiota of the human oral cavity or upper respiratory tract (Gemella, Abiotrophia, and Granulicatella) and skin (Helcococcus). Lactococci, vagococci, pediococci, and leuconostocs can be isolated from foods and vegetation and may also be found as part of the normal microbiota of the alimentary tract (7). Aerococci are environmental isolates that can also be found on human skin. Although they have been isolated from human clinical cultures, the natural habitats of many of the organisms mentioned here are not well characterized. The bacteria examined here seem to be of low virulence and are usually pathogenic in immunocompromised hosts. Infection often occurs in previously damaged tissues (e.g., heart valves) or may be nosocomial and associated with prolonged hospitalization, antibiotic treatment, invasive procedures, and the presence of foreign bodies.

sect2.title: CLINICAL SIGNIFICANCE
sect2.para: The bacteria described in this chapter may be present as contaminants in clinical cultures, but they are also isolated infrequently as opportunistic pathogens. Blood, cerebrospinal fluid, urine, and wound specimens are likely to yield significant isolates of these bacteria. Details on reported infections due to each of the genera follow.

sect1.title: Abiotrophia and Granulicatella
sect1.para: Organisms in the generaAbiotrophia and Granulicatella are normal residents of the oral cavity and are recognized as agents of endocarditis involving both native and prosthetic valves (44, 45). These organisms have also been isolated from other types of infections, including ophthalmic infections (46), central nervous system infections (47), peritonitis in patients undergoing continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis (48), musculoskeletal infection (49), septic arthritis (50), and a breast implant-associated infection (51).

sect1.title: Aerococcus
sect1.para: A. viridans has been noted as a contaminant in clinical cultures and infrequently as a clinically significant isolate from cases of endocarditis and bacteremia and a case of spondylodiscitis (52, 53). Four additional Aerococcus species isolated from humans have been described since the early 1990s. A. urinae (54) has been implicated as a urinary tract pathogen in patients predisposed to infection (approximately half of the patients have predisposing factors, either systemic [particularly diabetes mellitus and cancer] or local [indwelling catheter and/or hyperplasia of the prostate]) and as an agent of endocarditis (55), lymphadenitis (56), and peritonitis (57). A. sanguinicola has been isolated from blood and urine specimens (28, 29) and cases of urosepsis and endocarditis (55). Eight clinical A. sanguinicola strains and 40 clinical A. urinae strains from episodes of urinary tract infections, bacteremia, and infective endocarditis have been whole-genome sequenced and analyzed for genomic diversity and characterization of virulence genes involved in bacterial pathogenicity (58). Virulence genes associated with bacterial adhesion (A. sanguinicola: htpB, fbpA, lmb, and ilpA; A. urinae: htpB, lap, lmb, fbp-54, and ilpA) and antiphagocytosis (capsular polysaccharide gene homologs) were identified. Little is currently known about the clinical significance of A. christensenii (isolated from vaginal specimens [27] and A. urinaehominis (isolated from urine [30]).

sect1.title: Dolosicoccus
sect1.para: The single species of the genusDolosicoccus, D. paucivorans, has been described from three blood cultures; one strain from a patient with pneumonia and two strains from patients without clinical information (38, 59).

sect1.title: Dolosigranulum
sect1.para: Dolosigranulum is phenotypically similar, but not closely related, to Gemella (23). The single species of the genus, Dolosigranulum pigrum, has been associated with nosocomial pneumonia and septicemia, synovitis (60), acute cholecystitis accompanied by acute pancreatitis (61), and biomaterial-associated arthritis (62).

sect1.title: Facklamia
sect1.para: The genusFacklamia is closely related to, but phenotypically and phylogenetically distinct from, Globicatella (33). Strains of the four Facklamia species isolated from humans have been recovered from blood, wound, and genitourinary sites (33–36). F. hominis has been reported to cause a case of chorioamnionitis (63) and a case of infective endocarditis (64).

sect1.title: Gemella
sect1.para: The two most pathogenic species in the genusGemella are G. morbillorum and G. haemolysans, and the predominant clinical diseases caused by these two species are bacteremia/sepsis, infective endocarditis (65–67), brain abscess (68, 69), and bone and joint infections (70, 71). In addition, G. haemolysans has been isolated from meningitis (72) and ocular infections (73, 74), whereas G. morbillorum has been implicated in cases of liver abscesses, pleural empyemas and lung abscess (75), and peritonitis (76). Information on the clinical significance of the other Gemella species continues to accumulate. G. bergeri and G. sanguinis have been isolated from blood cultures, and they may also be causative agents of endocarditis (19, 20, 77). A strain of G. sanguinis was isolated from an infected prosthetic hip joint (78), and G. asaccharolytica has been isolated from wound cultures (21). G. parahaemolysans and G. taiwanensis have been isolated from blood cultures (22).

Based on the genomic and proteomic information available from NCBI, Garcia López and Martin-Galiano (79) found that a number of well-known virulence factors were harbored by all Gemella species, such as a manganese transport/adhesin sharing 83% identity with a protein from oral endocarditis-causing streptococci.

sect1.title: Globicatella
sect1.para: G. sanguinis, isolated from human clinical specimens, has been implicated in cases of bacteremia, urinary tract infection, osteomyelitis, and meningitis (32, 80, 81).

sect1.title: Helcococcus
sect1.para: H. kunzii can be isolated from intact skin of the lower extremities as well as from mixed cultures of wounds, notably foot infections (39). In such scenarios, the clinical significance of this organism is difficult to interpret, since it may be present merely as a colonizer of the wound site. The ability of H. kunzii to function as an opportunist is, however, suggested by its isolation as the sole or predominant organism from cases of skin and soft tissue abscesses, bacteremia, pleural empyema, prosthetic joint infection, and brain abscess (82). One additional species isolated from humans, H. sueciensis, is based on a single isolate from wound infection (40).

sect1.title: Ignavigranum
sect1.para: A limited number of isolates ofI. ruoffiae, the sole species of Ignavigranum, have been described to date. Sites of isolation include a wound and an ear abscess (37).

sect1.title: Lactococcus
sect1.para: Due to their phenotypic similarities with streptococci and enterococci, clinical isolates of lactococci have probably been misidentified in the past, accounting at least in part for the paucity of reports concerning the clinical role of these bacteria. Elliott and coworkers (83) studied the phenotypic characteristics of a number of lactococcal strains isolated from blood, urinary tract infections, and an eye wound culture. Lactococci have been associated with native-valve and prosthetic-valve endocarditis, septicemia in an immunosuppressed patient, osteomyelitis, spondylodiscitis (84), peritonitis (85), liver abscess (86), acalculous cholecystitis (87), and prosthetic joint infection (88). L. garvieae is a known pathogen of aquacultured fish, and human infections have been linked to consumption of or contact with fish (84, 88).

sect1.title: Leuconostoc
sect1.para: Leuconostoc, Pediococcus, and Weissella are three genera of catalase-negative Gram-positive coccoid bacteria that are innately resistant to vancomycin. The genera Leuconostoc and Pediococcus were first recognized in clinical specimens in the mid-1980s. Handwerger and colleagues (89) observed that host defense impairment, invasive procedures breaching the integument, gastrointestinal symptoms, and prior antibiotic treatment were common features among adult patients with Leuconostoc infection. They also noted a predisposition to Leuconostoc bacteremia among neonates, suggesting that infants may become colonized during delivery by Leuconostoc spp. inhabiting the maternal genital tract. Leuconostoc spp. have been isolated from blood, cerebrospinal fluid, peritoneal dialysate fluid, and wounds. Case reports have implicated Leuconostoc spp. as agents of infection in osteomyelitis (90), ventriculitis (91), brain abscess (92), postsurgical endophthalmitis (93), and bacteremia in the setting of short gut syndrome. Short gut syndrome favors a microbiota with a high prevalence of Lactobacillus and Leuconostoc bacteria (94). Several reports have related Leuconostoc bacteremic episodes to the presence of short gut syndrome, central venous catheters, and disrupted bowel mucosa (95).

sect1.title: Pediococcus
sect1.para: Pediococcus strains have been isolated from bacteremia and cases of sepsis and hepatic abscess in compromised patients (96, 97). Barros and coworkers (14) noted that P. acidilactici was isolated from clinical specimens more frequently than P. pentosaceus and was also more commonly isolated from cases of bacteremia. Barton and coworkers noted the role of Pediococcus in bacteremia in infants with gastrointestinal malformations requiring surgical correction (98).

sect1.title: Vagococcus
sect1.para: Vagococci are motile organisms that, like lactococci, express Lancefield group N antigen (7). Difficulties encountered in identifying vagococci may partially account for their infrequent recognition in clinical cultures. To date, only a few Vagococcus isolates from human sources have been reported. Teixeira and coworkers (99) described strains isolated from blood, peritoneal fluid, and a wound. Al-Ahmad and colleagues reported isolation of V. fluvialis from an infected root canal system (100). Vagococcus lutrae has been isolated from blood culture (101) and skin lesions (102). A newly recognized species, Vagococcus vulneris, was isolated from a human foot wound (6).

sect1.title: Weissella
sect1.para: Weissella strains are usually isolated in polymicrobial infections. They are often confused with Lactobacillus or viridans streptococci and may be considered contaminants (103). Weissella confusa, formerly classified as Lactobacillus confusus, has been reported infrequently as an agent of bacteremia, endocarditis, prosthetic joint infections, abscesses (103), and meningitis (104). Weissella cibaria isolates have been identified in the urine, lung, and blood of patients with bacteremia. W. viridescens has been recovered from human blood. The clinical significance of infections with these species is not yet clear (13, 103).

sect2.title: COLLECTION, TRANSPORT, AND STORAGE OF SPECIMENS
sect2.para: No special requirements for collection and transport of specimens for isolation of the organisms discussed in this chapter have been described. Routine procedures for collection, transport, and storage of specimens for aerobic culture allow the isolation of these bacteria, since the majority are facultative anaerobes or microaerophiles. These organisms may also be recovered from specimens that have been collected and transported under anaerobic conditions (seechapter 19).

sect2.title: DIRECT EXAMINATION
sect2.para: The organisms described in this chapter can be visualized in direct Gram stains of clinical material but have no outstanding morphological characteristics that distinguish them from commonly isolated Gram-positive cocci (streptococci and staphylococci). AlthoughAbiotrophia and Granulicatella isolates may appear pleomorphic in direct Gram stains, they form Gram-positive cocci in pairs and chains when grown on nutritionally adequate media. Direct detection of these genera by antigenic methods has not been described. Amplification and sequencing of 16S rRNA genes and matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization–time-of-flight mass spectrometry (MALDI-TOF MS) have been evaluated for direct or rapid detection of these organisms in clinical specimens (105–107).

sect2.title: ISOLATION PROCEDURES
sect2.para: Generally, there are no special requirements for isolation of the group of bacteria discussed here; general recommendations for the culture of blood, body fluids, and other specimens should be followed (seechapter 19). These organisms are likely to be isolated on rich, nonselective media (e.g., blood or chocolate agar and thioglycolate broth), since they are nutritionally fastidious. If selective isolation of the vancomycin-resistant genera Leuconostoc and Pediococcus is desired, Thayer-Martin medium may be used to inhibit the normal microbiota or other contaminating microorganisms (108). Some of the genera (e.g., Helcococcus) grow slowly, forming tiny colonies that may not be visible unless extended incubation (48 to 72 h) is employed. The recovery of many of the genera included in this chapter may be enhanced by CO2 enrichment of the incubation atmosphere. Members of the genera Abiotrophia and Granulicatella usually grow on chocolate agar, on brucella agar with 5% horse blood, and in thioglycolate broth but not on Trypticase soy agar with 5% sheep blood. These organisms can be cultured on nonsupportive media that have been appropriately supplemented (see “Abiotrophia and Granulicatella” in “Procedures for Phenotypic Differentiation” below).

sect1.title: Procedures for Phenotypic Differentiation
sect1.para: While molecular characterization may be required for accurate species-level identification of the aerobic catalase-negative, Gram-positive cocci encountered infrequently in clinical laboratories, phenotypic methods can be helpful in characterization of these bacteria to the genus level. Gram stain morphology has been employed as a major decision point in the identification protocols inFig. 1 and 2 and Table 1, with two general categories: morphology resembling that of streptococci, meaning cocci or coccobacilli in pairs and chains, and staphylococcal morphology, consisting of coccoid cells arranged in pairs, clusters, tetrads, or irregular groups. Figure 3 shows microscopic morphology of type strains from 11 species. Broth-grown cells (thioglycolate broth is suitable) should be used for making accurate morphological determinations. Note that Gemella and Facklamia strains may display either type of cellular morphology, depending on the species. Figures 1 and 2 display phenotypic tests used to differentiate the genera of bacteria discussed in this chapter. Descriptions of tests for catalase, PYR, LAP, β-glucuronidase, and hippurate hydrolysis, as well as bile esculin agar and Lactobacillus MRS (DeMan, Rogosa, Sharpe) broth medium, can be found in reference 7. Additional phenotypic tests are described below in the discussion of identification criteria for each genus.

sect2.title: Abiotrophia and Granulicatella
sect2.para: A test for satelliting behavior is important for identification ofAbiotrophia and Granulicatella. The strain to be examined is streaked for confluent growth on a medium that does not support growth or supports only weak growth (e.g., sheep blood agar). A single cross streak of Staphylococcus aureus (ATCC 25923 or another suitable strain) is applied to the inoculated area. After incubation at 35°C in an atmosphere containing elevated CO2, strains of Abiotrophia or Granulicatella grow only in the vicinity of the staphylococcal growth. Some strains of Ignavigranum may also show satelliting behavior (37). Alternatively, media can be supplemented with pyridoxal. An aqueous stock solution of filter-sterilized 0.01% pyridoxal hydrochloride (which can be stored frozen) should be added to media to achieve a final concentration of 0.001%. Pyridoxal disks (Remel, Thermo Fisher Scientific, Waltham, MA) may also be used in the satelliting test. Detailed phenotypic information for the PYR- and LAP-positive Abiotrophia and Granulicatella species can be found in references 8, 42, 109, and 110.

sect2.title: Aerococcus
sect2.para: The PYR-positive, LAP-negative member of the genusAerococcus, A. viridans, is characterized by displaying weak or no growth when incubated in an anaerobic atmosphere (111). This trait can be tested by incubating duplicate blood agar plate cultures of the organism in question in anaerobic and aerobic atmospheres and comparing growth after 24 to 48 h. A. viridans forms alpha-hemolytic colonies that could be confused with those of either viridans group streptococci or enterococci. A. sanguinicola is positive in the PYR and LAP tests, while A. urinaehominis is negative in both. The PYR-negative, LAP-positive species, A. urinae and A. christensenii, are differentiated by production of β-glucuronidase (A. christensenii is negative and A. urinae is positive). A. urinae forms small (0.5 mm in diameter after 24 h of incubation), alpha-hemolytic, convex, shiny, transparent colonies on blood agar media. Additional information on the identifying characteristics of A. urinae can be found in reference 112, and a second biotype (esculin hydrolysis positive) of this species is described in reference 26. Additional information on phenotypic traits of the species A. christensenii, A. sanguinicola, and A. urinaehominis can be found in Table 1, Fig. 2, and references 27–30.

sect2.title: Dolosigranulum
sect2.para: D. pigrum, the sole species of Dolosigranulum described to date, displays positive PYR and LAP reactions and was initially described as phenotypically similar, though not closely related, to members of the genus Gemella (23). D. pigrum is distinguished from Gemella spp. by its abilities to hydrolyze arginine and to grow in the presence of 6.5% NaCl.

sect2.title: Gemella
sect2.para: On sheep blood agar media, members of the genusGemella (usually PYR positive) form small colonies that are similar in appearance to those of viridans-group streptococci. Slow growth of some Gemella strains may lead to confusion of these organisms with Abiotrophia or Granulicatella. A test for satelliting behavior should separate these two groups of bacteria (113), but Leung and coworkers (78) reported a single G. sanguinis strain that exhibited “pseudosatelliting” behavior (satelliting growth after 24 h but widespread growth after 48 h of incubation). Cells of G. haemolysans are easily decolorized and resemble those of neisseriae, since they occur in pairs with the adjacent sides flattened. G. haemolysans grows best in an aerobic atmosphere. The esculin hydrolysis test for differentiation of G. haemolysans and R. mucilaginosa listed in Fig. 2 is performed with esculin agar slants (heart infusion agar containing 0.1% esculin and 0.5% ferric citrate) that are inoculated and incubated at 35°C for up to 7 days. Partial or complete blackening of the agar indicates a positive reaction (7). G. morbillorum cells are Gram positive and arranged in pairs and short chains; individual cells in a given pair may be of unequal sizes. Only a small number of strains of G. bergeri and G. sanguinis have been reported to date. Information on phenotypic characteristics of these Gemella species can be found in references 19 and 20. The recently described G. asaccharolytica is PYR negative, unlike other Gemella species (21). Phenotypic characteristics of G. parahaemolysans and G. taiwanensis are summarized in reference 22.

sect2.title: Globicatella and Related Genera (Facklamia, Dolosicoccus, and Ignavigranum)
sect2.para: Globicatella and the related genera Facklamia, Dolosicoccus, and Ignavigranum are all, with the exception of the species Globicatella sulfidifaciens, PYR positive. Facklamia and Ignavigranum are also LAP positive and salt tolerant. Globicatella is LAP negative and salt tolerant, while Dolosicoccus is LAP negative and salt intolerant. Dolosicoccus strains are also hippurate hydrolysis negative, which further distinguishes them from strains of Facklamia and Globicatella (hippurate hydrolysis positive). Strains of F. hominis and Ignavigranum may produce urease. Ignavigranum strains may exhibit satelliting behavior. Further details of phenotypic traits of these organisms can be found in references 33–38, and 114.

sect2.title: Helcococcus
sect2.para: Colonial morphology (tiny, gray, usually slightly alpha-hemolytic colonies), good growth under anaerobic conditions, and stimulation of growth by the addition of 1% horse serum or 0.1% Tween 80 to the medium differentiateH. kunzii from aerococci (39). Isolates of H. kunzii are PYR positive. An additional Helcococcus species isolated from humans, H. sueciensis, is negative in the PYR test. Detailed phenotypic data on these organisms can be found in references 39, 40, and 41.

sect2.title: Lactococcus and Vagococcus
sect2.para: The members of the generaLactococcus and Vagococcus are usually PYR and LAP positive, grow in the presence of 6.5% NaCl, and can be confused with enterococci or streptococci. For the salt tolerance test, heart infusion broth supplemented with 6.0% NaCl (producing a final NaCl concentration of 6.5%), with or without the acid-base indicator bromcresol purple, is inoculated with two or three colonies and incubated at 35°C for up to 72 h. Turbidity with or without a color change from purple to yellow indicates growth (7, 113). Facklam and colleagues (7, 113) recommended growth temperature tests for distinguishing lactococci from streptococci and enterococci. Consult Fig. 1 for growth temperature characteristics of each of the genera. For growth temperature tests, broths (heart infusion broth containing 1% glucose and bromcresol purple indicator) are inoculated with a single colony or drop of broth culture of the test strain and incubated at 35°C for up to 7 days. A water bath is recommended for incubation of cultures at 45°C. Turbidity with or without a change in the broth’s indicator to yellow indicates a positive test. The motile vagococci can be distinguished from lactococci with modified motility test medium, stab inoculated, and incubated at 30°C for up to 48 h, according to the method of Facklam and Elliott (7). Further information on the phenotypic traits of Lactococcus and Vagococcus isolates may be found in references 3, 83, 99, and 115.

sect2.title: Leuconostoc, Pediococcus, and Weissella
sect2.para: Members of the PYR-negative, vancomycin-resistant generaLeuconostoc, Pediococcus, and Weissella produce small, alpha-hemolytic or nonhemolytic colonies on blood agar. Vancomycin resistance can be tested for identification purposes by streaking several colonies over half of a plate containing Trypticase soy agar with 5% sheep blood. After a 30-μg vancomycin disk has been placed in the center of the inoculated area, the plate is incubated overnight in a CO2-enriched atmosphere at 35°C. Any zone of inhibition indicates susceptibility, while resistant strains exhibit no inhibition zone (7, 113). In addition to having different cellular morphologies (Table 1), these vancomycin-resistant genera, along with vancomycin-resistant strains of lactobacilli that form short coccoid cells, can be differentiated by tests for gas production from glucose and arginine hydrolysis. Leuconostoc spp. produce gas and are always arginine negative. Lactobacilli are variable in both tests, but a positive arginine test for a gas-producing strain would rule out identification of the organism as a leuconostoc. Pediococci are gas production negative and show variable reactions in the arginine test, although P. acidilactici and P. pentosaceus, the two species commonly found in clinical material, are arginine positive.

Weissella strains may be misidentified as Leuconostoc spp. or lactobacilli. These organisms produce gas from glucose. The few clinical isolates reported in the literature have been described as positive for hydrolysis of arginine (12). MRS broth (BD Diagnostic Systems, Franklin Lakes, NJ; Hardy Diagnostics, Santa Maria, CA), sealed with melted petrolatum and incubated for up to 7 days at 35°C, is used to test for gas production, indicated by displacement of the petrolatum plug (7, 113). The arginine hydrolysis test can be performed with Moeller decarboxylase broth containing arginine (7). Lancefield group D antigen can be detected in pediococci (113). References 7, 11, 14, and 113 should be consulted for further information on identification of Leuconostoc and Pediococcus to the species level.

sect1.title: Commercially Available Kits and Automated Methods Based on Phenotypic Traits
sect1.para: There have been no comprehensive evaluations of the ability of commercially available products to identify the diverse and infrequently isolated bacteria described in this chapter. Phenotypic variation among isolates classified in the same species, the relative metabolic inactivity of some organisms, and a relatively small number of strains available for inclusion in databases have challenged the capabilities of these products for accurate identification. Manual methods for performance of some of the basic differentiation tests (e.g., PYR and LAP) are available (e.g., Remel BactiCard Strep; Thermo Fisher Scientific). Commercially available identification kits or systems offering a more comprehensive array of phenotypic tests are improving in their ability to identify many of the organisms discussed in this chapter (28, 114, 116–118). These products include manual methods, e.g., API 20 Strep, and automated systems, e.g., VITEK 2 (bioMérieux), MicroScan (Beckman Coulter, Brea, CA), and Phoenix (BD, Franklin Lakes, NJ). In the absence of an accurate genus- or species-level identification, these systems will at least provide additional phenotypic information that can be used to augment results of the basic tests mentioned above.

sect2.title: Sequence-Based Techniques
sect2.para: 16S rRNA gene sequencing-based identifications have proven to be more accurate than phenotypic methods for identifying many of the infrequently isolated aerobic catalase-negative, Gram-positive cocci (116, 118). Bosshard and colleagues (116) analyzed 171 clinical strains of the genera Streptococcus, Enterococcus, Abiotrophia, Aerococcus, Granulicatella, and Gemella and observed that more species- or genus-level identifications were achieved via 16S rRNA gene sequence analysis than by a commercially available phenotypic method (API 20 Strep). Identifications based on phenotypic traits often disagreed with those determined by 16S rRNA gene sequencing. Woo and coworkers (118) examined strains of Abiotrophia, Granulicatella, Gemella, and Helcococcus in their evaluation of a commercially available 16S rRNA gene sequence-based identification system that analyzes a 527-bp fragment of the 16S rRNA gene (MicroSeq 500; Life Technologies, Foster City, CA). They noted disagreement in identifications obtained with commercially available phenotypic test systems (API 20 Strep and VITEK) and MicroSeq 500 compared with conventional sequencing of the entire 16S rRNA gene. The authors stressed the importance of adequate databases for accurate rRNA gene sequence-based identification. Different regions of the 16S rRNA gene have been used for identification. The first 500 bp is the most commonly applied target for identification (119). The entire 16S rRNA gene (1.5 kb) has also been sequenced when more-detailed descriptions of taxa or strains are being made (120). 16S rRNA gene sequencing is an effective method for identifying the genera included in this chapter, many of which are difficult to identify with conventional phenotypic methods (120, 121). Accumulating data on the clinical significance of species make it possible to link an accurate species identification to clinically relevant information (120). Other reports on identification of strains of the genera Aerococcus, Granulicatella, and Globicatella support the benefits of using 16S rRNA gene sequencing for these genera (42, 122–125).

Broad-range amplification of the 16S rRNA gene directly from clinical samples has made it possible to detect taxa described in this chapter from various clinical samples yielding no growth in culture (for instance,G. elegans and A. urinae from cardiac valvular tissue [126, 127]). A major challenge for this methodology when the Sanger method is used is the difficulty in analyzing sequence data when multiple bacterial species are present in the same specimen. Kommedal and coworkers used a set of group-specific, broad-range primers targeting the 16S rRNA gene followed by DNA sequencing and RipSeq analysis (iSentio AS, Paradis, Norway) and identified Gemella species from abscess material also containing bacterial DNA from other taxa (128). When clinical samples are being examined, cross-reactivity with human DNA is a major pitfall that can result in mixed electropherograms, complicating subsequent sequence analysis and species identification. Kommedal and colleagues employed the principle of dual-priming oligonucleotides to circumvent cross-reactivity even in specimens with a high ratio of human to bacterial DNA (129).

Alternative sequencing targets for identification of the organisms discussed in this chapter have also been explored. PCR amplification of a 740-bprpoB gene fragment followed by sequence analysis was shown to be a suitable molecular approach for the species-level identification of Streptococcus, Enterococcus, Gemella, Abiotrophia, and Granulicatella isolates by Drancourt and colleagues (130). Hung et al. (131) determined the groESL sequences of three species of nutritionally variant streptococci and three Gemella species and developed a multiplex PCR enabling identification of strains of Abiotrophia, Granulicatella, and Gemella at the genus level. To a large extent, intraspecies sequences were well circumscribed, though higher intraspecies heterogeneity was observed in G. haemolysans, with the six isolates examined being separated into two subgroups.

Tung and coworkers (132) evaluated the feasibility of sequence analysis of the ribosomal 16S-23S intergenic spacer region (ITS) for identification of 24 species of Streptococcus, 1 species of Abiotrophia, 18 species of Enterococcus, and 3 species of Granulicatella. The rate of correct species identification by ITS sequence analysis was 98.2%. However, all of the genera except Streptococcus produced more than one PCR amplicon, necessitating agarose gel separation and in some cases cloning to purify the amplicons before sequencing. Tung and colleagues (133) further developed an array-based identification setup based on PCR amplification of the ITS regions and found it to be a useful and reliable alternative to phenotypic identification methods. The approach of having a single molecular platform for strains resembling nonhemolytic streptococci, enterococci, and the taxa considered in this chapter based on ITS analysis has also been examined by Nielsen and colleagues (134). Clinical strains of the genera Aerococcus (n = 37), Abiotrophia (n = 2), Granulicatella (n = 9), Gemella (n = 22), and Leuconostoc (n = 5) were examined. All 75 clinical strains, irrespective of the maximum score obtained, were allocated to the expected species except for two strains of Gemella.

Phylogeny, identification, and virulence characterization based on whole-genome sequence (WGS) data or extracts thereof are and will be increasingly possible and available for many taxa with the rapidly increasing use of next-generation sequencing technology (seechapter 8). Whole-genome sequences from all genera and species mentioned in this chapter as having been recognized as clinically significant for humans can be retrieved from https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/genome/. However, the WGS workflow needs to be improved further to be implemented as a routine method for identification of the species mentioned in this chapter.

sect2.title: MALDI-TOF MS Techniques
sect2.para: MALDI-TOF MS (seechapter 6) for analysis of bacterial proteins is a promising technique for identification of the bacteria mentioned in this chapter. In Tables 1 and 2 of chapter 20, a number of genera and species included in the most recently updated in vitro diagnostic databases from Bruker and bioMérieux are given; research-use-only databases exist for both systems. The mass spectrometry setups are constantly being improved, and the misidentification rate for even rare and seldom-seen taxa is low and diminishing. Christensen and coworkers (135) examined 51 culture collection strains and 90 well-characterized strains with the Bruker Biotyper system. A mass spectrum profile (MSP) based on 24 separate determinations was created for each strain and stored in a separate library that could be combined with the standard database (Biotyper version 2.0.43.1), which did not include all the taxa examined. The following genera were represented: Aerococcus (n = 42), Gemella (n = 30), Granulicatella (n = 11), Abiotrophia (n = 3), Lactococcus (n = 9), Globicatella (n = 7), Leuconostoc (n = 9), Rothia (n = 9), Facklamia (n = 7), Vagococcus (n = 2), Helcococcus (n = 4), Alloiococcus (n = 2), Pediococcus (n = 3), Ignavigranum (n = 1), Dolosicoccus (n = 1), and Dolosigranulum (n = 1). The protocol for creating one’s own MSPs in a separate library, though somewhat labor-intensive, makes it possible to extend the database. After extension of the database, all challenge strains were correctly identified to the species level except for a few difficult-to-identify Gemella strains. The mean scores obtained illustrated diversity within the different species and an effect on mean scores of different conditions for creating MSPs. The MSP dendrograms for Aerococcus, Gemella, Granulicatella, and Abiotrophia convincingly delineated the included species. Thus, for routine use, MALDI-TOF MS was shown to be robust. In a study by Rychert et al., 1,146 strains of Gram-positive cocci were examined with the VITEK MS version 2.0 system (136). Fifteen of these strains belonged to taxa described in this chapter: A. defectiva (n = 2), A. viridans (n = 6), G. haemolysans (n = 3), G. adiacens (n = 1), L. garvieae (n = 1), L. lactis (n = 1), and L. mesenteroides (n = 1). All strains were correctly identified except the L. mesenteroides strain, which gave no identification. Other studies have corroborated the usefulness of MALDI-TOF MS for identification of aerococci (137), Lactococcus species (138, 139), and Leuconostoc (139) species and have investigated using this technique for identification of Weissella and Pediococcus strains (140).

sect2.title: TYPING SYSTEMS
sect2.para: Little information exists on typing methods for the genera of infrequently isolated Gram-positive cocci included in this chapter. Typing is not routinely used for characterizing these organisms. If needed, typing could be done by DNA sequence analysis (141).

sect2.title: SEROLOGIC TESTS
sect2.para: The serologic response to the organisms described in this chapter has not been extensively investigated. No clinically useful tests have been described.

sect2.title: ANTIMICROBIAL SUSCEPTIBILITIES
sect2.para: Antimicrobial susceptibility studies on the organisms mentioned in this chapter have generally employed dilution testing methods. Few or no data exist on the utility of disk diffusion or the correlation of Etest results with those of broth or agar dilution methods. Standardized dilution methods and interpretive criteria for observed MICs have been described by the Clinical and Laboratory Standards Institute (CLSI) for seven of the genera (Aerococcus, Abiotrophia, Gemella, Granulicatella, Lactococcus, Leuconostoc, and Pediococcus [142] [see chapter 77]). EUCAST recommendations for A. urinae and A. sanguinicola were included in 2017 (143). The lack of standardized methods and interpretive criteria and the relatively small collections of isolates for some of the genera discussed in this chapter make it difficult to accurately assess antimicrobial susceptibility patterns. With the exception of Leuconostoc, Pediococcus, and Weissella, all of the genera display susceptibility to vancomycin. While many of the genera are susceptible to β-lactams and other antimicrobials, observed strain variations suggest that MICs of antimicrobials used for treatment should be determined for individual isolates. When susceptibility testing is requested for isolates for which no guidelines exist, dilution methods may be used to generate MICs that can be reported without interpretation. The laboratory should discuss the implications of nonstandardized susceptibility testing results with the requesting physician. Since many of the bacteria discussed here are fastidious, investigators have often employed blood-supplemented Mueller-Hinton media and, if necessary for good growth, incubation in a CO2-enriched atmosphere for susceptibility testing. Pyridoxal hydrochloride (final concentration of 0.001%) should also be added to blood-supplemented media for testing strains of Abiotrophia and Granulicatella (142). Details of published susceptibility testing studies for each of the genera appear below.

Information on thein vitro antimicrobial susceptibility of L. lactis and L. garvieae strains isolated from humans suggests that L. garvieae isolates are less susceptible to penicillin and cephalothin than are strains of L. lactis. The uniform resistance of L. garvieae to clindamycin versus the uniform susceptibility of the L. lactis strains examined by Elliott and Facklam (115) led them to propose a test for clindamycin susceptibility as an aid in differentiation of these two species. Teixeira and colleagues (99) observed that a collection of Vagococcus isolates were all susceptible to ampicillin, cefotaxime, and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. All strains were resistant to clindamycin, lomefloxacin, and ofloxacin. Variable results were observed with other antimicrobial agents (99).

The vancomycin-resistant generaLeuconostoc and Pediococcus are penicillin susceptible when MICs are interpreted by using criteria for Enterococcus spp. (142, 144). They are usually susceptible to chloramphenicol, tetracyclines, and aminoglycosides. Carbapenem and cephalosporin resistance has been noted in some strains of Leuconostoc (91). Huang and colleagues (145) noted MIC ranges of 0.5 to 8 μg/ml for linezolid and 0.06 to 2 μg/ml for daptomycin in 68 strains of Leuconostoc and ranges of 1 to 4 μg/ml for linezolid and 0.06 to 0.5 μg/ml for daptomycin in 13 Pediococcus isolates. Iwen and colleagues reported the successful treatment of a case of P. acidilactici endocarditis with daptomycin (146).

Susceptibility data onAbiotrophia and Granulicatella isolates are accumulating. Data on series of 39 (147), 132 (148), 134 (149), and 599 (150) isolates have been published in more recent years. Approximately 70 to 85% of isolates belonged to G. adiacens, 20 to 30% belonged to A. defectiva, and only relatively few isolates belonged to G. elegans (up to 20 isolates [150]). Studies have demonstrated the same trends in susceptibility patterns. Broth microdilution MIC determinations as well as the Etest method have been employed. However, in the study by Alberti et al. (151) on 125 Abiotrophia and Granulicatella strains, the Etest performed poorly with vancomycin and, although to a lesser extent, with penicillin and ceftriaxone. Only 10 to 14% of A. defectiva and 34 to 44% of G. adiacens isolates were recorded as susceptible to penicillin. Interestingly, G. elegans isolates were significantly more susceptible to penicillin, as 80% (16/20) of isolates in the study by Prasidthrathsint and Fisher (150) were susceptible. Among penicillin-susceptible G. adiacens isolates, only 65% were susceptible to ceftriaxone, and of the penicillin-resistant isolates, 95% were also resistant to ceftriaxone (150). In the studies by Alberti et al. and Mushtaq et al. (148, 149), only 22 to 44% of G. adiacens isolates were susceptible to ceftriaxone. Prasidthrathsint and Fisher (150) found that the majority of penicillin-susceptible A. defectiva isolates (95%) remained susceptible to ceftriaxone, whereas 97% of penicillin-resistant A. defectiva isolates remained susceptible to ceftriaxone. In the studies by Alberti et al. and Mushtaq et al. on A. defectiva isolates, 92 to 100% of isolates were susceptible to ceftriaxone. Reduced susceptibility to meropenem has been observed for 10 and 20% of G. adiacens and A. defectiva isolates, respectively, and MICs of ≥2 μg/ml have been observed for 2.4% and 0.6% of isolates, respectively (150).

Susceptibility to aminoglycosides is also variable forAbiotrophia and Granulicatella, but no cases of high-level resistance have been reported. Treatment regimens for infective endocarditis outlined for A. defectiva and Granulicatella species are subdivided into categories based on penicillin MIC data (152). Macrolide resistance, especially to erythromycin, has been documented in several studies, though one study found that all 39 strains were susceptible (147, 148, 150, 153). Strains have tested susceptible to rifampin and quinupristin-dalfopristin (147), and most strains have tested susceptible to the quinolones levofloxacin and ofloxacin (147, 150), though resistant strains have occurred (148, 150). Daptomycin MICs have ranged from ≤0.125 to >4 μg/ml (148, 154); in the study by Alberti and coworkers, the MIC90 was >4 μg/ml for strains of G. adiacens and A. defectiva. Five G. elegans isolates tested 100% susceptible to 14 antimicrobials, with the exception of erythromycin, to which only one strain was susceptible.

A. viridans and G. haemolysans appear to be susceptible to penicillin and display a low level of resistance to aminoglycosides (155, 156). Resistance to tetracycline and macrolides in Gemella isolates has been described (157), as well as a synergistic effect for penicillin and gentamicin (156). Piper and colleagues (154) noted daptomycin MICs of ≤0.125 μg/ml for four strains of G. morbillorum. Buu-Hoi and colleagues (155) noted that while A. viridans seems to be naturally susceptible to macrolides, tetracyclines, and chloramphenicol, resistance to these agents has been observed. A. urinae has been described as susceptible to penicillin, amoxicillin, piperacillin, cefepime, rifampin, and nitrofurantoin but resistant to sulfonamides and netilmicin (112, 158, 159). Humphries and coworkers (160) noted that A. urinae’s resistance to trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is test medium dependent. Strains of this organism are susceptible to trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole when tested on media that contain lysed horse blood and display low levels of thymidine. A. sanguinicola isolates display susceptibility to penicillin, amoxicillin, cefotaxime, cefuroxime, erythromycin, chloramphenicol, quinupristin-dalfopristin, rifampin, linezolid, and tetracycline (28).

Clinical isolates ofD. pigrum studied by Laclaire and Facklam (24) were all susceptible to penicillin, amoxicillin, cefotaxime, cefuroxime, clindamycin, levofloxacin, meropenem, quinupristin-dalfopristin, rifampin, and tetracycline. Variable susceptibility to erythromycin was noted, and 1 of the 27 strains examined was resistant to trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.

Helcococcus infections have been treated with amoxicillin-clavulanate, fluoroquinolones, and third-generation cephalosporins, but comprehensive data on antimicrobial susceptibilities of these organisms are lacking (82). Recently, Guérin and coworkers (161) described a novel chromosomeal erm(47) determinant responsible for constitutive macrolide-lincosamide-streptogramin B resistance in Helcococcus kunzii. Strains of Facklamia exhibit variable MICs for a variety of antibiotics. LaClaire and Facklam (162) investigated antimicrobial susceptibility for 15 antimicrobial agents using a microdilution method on 18 strains of the Facklamia species from human samples. While 83% of the strains were susceptible to penicillin (MIC ≤ 0.12 μg/ml), only 54% were susceptible to cefotaxime (MIC ≤ 1 μg/ml) and 67% were susceptible to cefuroxime. Differences in susceptibilities among Facklamia species were observed, too. A study of 27 strains of Globicatella sanguinis investigated 12 antimicrobial agents using a microdilution method. All isolates had low MICs and were susceptible to amoxicillin (MIC ≤ 0.03 μg/ml) and vancomycin (MIC ≤ 0.12 μg/ml). The MIC range for penicillin was ≤0.03 to 0.50 μg/ml, and two strains were intermediate to penicillin according to CLSI breakpoints. However, the MICs of cephalosporins were higher than those of penicillins. Forty-eight percent of strains were resistant to cefotaxime (MIC range, 0.06 to 4.0 μg/ml) and 74% of strains were resistant to cefuroxime (MIC range, 0.12 to 16). Various levels of resistance to other antimicrobial agents tested were observed; for instance, 37% were resistant to meropenem, and 48% were resistant to erythromycin (163).

sect2.title: EVALUATION, INTERPRETATION, AND REPORTING OF RESULTS
sect2.para: Efforts to identify the Gram-positive cocci included in this chapter should be made only when isolates are considered clinically significant (i.e., isolated repeatedly, in pure culture, or from normally sterile sites), since these organisms may also appear in clinical cultures as contaminants or constituents of the normal microbiota. Communication with clinicians should guide the microbiology laboratory in evaluating the significance of these infrequently isolated organisms. The phenotypic tests mentioned inTable 1 and Fig. 1 and 2 facilitate presumptive identification of the infrequently isolated catalase-negative, Gram-positive cocci. More extensive phenotypic testing using commercially available identification systems and molecular methods should be employed for definitive identification. Currently, there are susceptibility testing guidelines for only seven of the genera mentioned in this chapter. The MICs generated with dilution methods can be reported without interpretation when susceptibility testing is requested for significant isolates for which no guidelines exist.

Abiotrophia, Granulicatella, and Gemella species are well-documented agents of endocarditis. The satelliting behavior of Abiotrophia and Granulicatella and the positive PYR reactions of all three genera are useful for distinguishing them from viridans-group streptococci. CLSI guidelines (142) should be employed for susceptibility testing and interpretation of results for Abiotrophia and Granulicatella. The vancomycin-resistant genera Leuconostoc, Pediococcus, and Weissella are infrequent clinical isolates, but they have been described as agents of bacteremia and central nervous system and other infections in compromised hosts. Phenotypic testing for vancomycin resistance (see “Identification” above) is important for identifying these genera and also helps guide antimicrobial therapy. Guidelines for antimicrobial susceptibility testing and interpretation of results are available for Leuconostoc and Pediococcus (142). Among the aerococci, A. urinae and A. sanguinicola are well-documented urinary tract pathogens and should be reported when isolated in significant amounts as the predominant organism in urine cultures. Phenotypic tests mentioned in this chapter presumptively identify A. urinae, which has been described as susceptible to β-lactam agents and nitrofurantoin (112, 158).
